instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hello,

i have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board which won't turn on. I inspected the board and it doesn't have any corrosion or burned components. All fuses are ok! I mesured <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL>. It has instead of 20V, only 5,2V. <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> also has 5,2v

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> 5,2v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR_R</SIGNAL> 5,2v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_R</SIGNAL> 0v

If you need any other values, please let me know.
Can anybody tell me how to find the faulty component ?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> present and if not is it shorted to GND, diode mode measurement?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi and thanks for your reply.

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> 0v and not shorted to ground.

All coils on the board have 0v.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Voltages on all pins of <DIODE>D6902</DIODE>? Charger connected of course.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Pin 3 <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> 5,2v
Pin 1 <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR_R</SIGNAL> 5,2v
Pin 2 <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_R</SIGNAL> 0v

Charger is Brand new from apple store and plugged in.?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Check again for 3V on L6900 as the input to <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> seems fine. Check voltage on <RESISTOR>R6921</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
l6900 0v and <RESISTOR>R6921</RESISTOR> 5,2v

for one moment it had the right values  but after that, always the values i wrote bevore

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: So enable is present to <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> and it is receiving power from <DIODE>D6902</DIODE>. I would actually expect 3V on <RESISTOR>R6921</RESISTOR> so make sure you are measuring the correct thing.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: i mesured the wrong resistor, the value of <RESISTOR>R6921</RESISTOR> is 0v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Check around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Is there voltage on L7030? <SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
l7030 0V and <SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 0,9V 

Do you have any messenger? Otherwise we maybe need a few weeks to find the faulty component or IC:D

thx a lot!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
What is the voltage on <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR>? I'm starting to suspect a bad <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

My direct messenger is available for $100 an hour if you really insist.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
I Changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and it works now.

thank you very much!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Awesome! Another chip I need to get in stock then. It was probably killed by a shit Chinese charger or cable.
